Now we turn to Bertram Marks to talk about how the scandal is affecting the Detroit community.
He's an attorney for the Council of Baptist Pastors for Detroit and Vicinity.
Thanks for coming on.
It's my pleasure to be here.
Thank you for having me.

Let me start out by noting that someone gave me a call, one of our listeners from Detroit gave me a call and said that he thought that on our show, as in many other venues, that this mayor was not getting a fair shake.
Are there a lot of people who believe that this is unwanted prosecution or persecution of the mayor?
I couldn't say that a lot of people believe that.
And let me just say this.
What I know about the local affiliate here, if I can call it that, this is probably one of the most balanced and fair forums that you're going to get.
And so I think it's a bit disingenuous to suggest that somehow the press has created the mess we're in right now.
I just don't get that from a majority of the people that are talking to the pastors that I represent.
I think the feeling is probably better expressed in terms of frustration, in terms of disbelief.
There is a willingness to be forgiving.
But there is also this notion of accountability.
And often when people turn to the faith community, they say - even politicians will often say - well, you're supposed to be forgiving.
Yes, the faith community is forgiving, but there is also accountability that is attached to forgiveness, and I think that's where most of the people that we're talking to are expressing.
That seems to be their general sentiment.
Nobody wants to see this mayor, his family, this city suffer through this devastating situation.
We're hoping that it can be resolved quickly.
When you think about politics today, there's been a spate of people having to face sexual revelations; Spitzer and Patterson in New York, Kilpatrick.
But this is not - the prosecution, the legal prosecution, is not about sex.
It's about, you know, lying under oath and questions like that.
Nonetheless, you know, as someone who works in the faith community, is sex what's making people pay attention to this or is it these larger issues of corporate and city governance and propriety?
I mean how are people relating to this, do you think?
There's where we are getting some mixed views.
Some people do believe this is a situation that's simply involves the mayor and his wife.

I don't believe that average citizens have educated themselves on the issues, the deeper issues, the issues that affect his oath of office, the issues that affect his fiduciary responsibility as it relates to being the mayor.
I don't think people are looking at the actions that were taken relative to the police officers who were discharged and why they were discharged.
If people would look at those issues, I think they'd probably formulate different opinions.

But it would be disingenuous for me not to say that, absolutely, we have heard from some of our constituents that, you know, this is a private affair of the mayor's; why is the press digging into this; if - or but for this, these sexual revelations, this would be a non-issue.
Do you believe that the prosecutor, Wayne County prosecutor Kym Worthy, is taking on the establishment by pursuing this case?
I don't.
What I know about Kym Worthy is that she is a very fair-minded individual and she's also a very focused individual.
I don't think that any of the ramifications of these charges one way or the other have influenced what she decided to do.
I think she looked at the situation, made an informed judgment and determined that she had to bring charges.
I just don't view her as sort of taking on the establishment.
Now, the effect of what she's done is going to reverberate through the establishment.
I think that she's ushering in a new era in Detroit politics.
One which says that, you know, you've got to place a very high value on integrity and on transparency and on being open and honest when communicating with the city.

And my hope, my prayer is that the mayor, no matter what happens in the situation, and not just the mayor but politicians who are coming forward, politicians who are sitting now, get that message, that integrity does mean something and honesty is the best policy.
What role if any does the faith community have in making sure that as these things unfold people are in a position to advocate for themselves as citizens and make good decisions?

I think the role of the faith community is critical, and if you look at the faith community's role throughout history, it should be to be a prophetic voice, to be a voice for voiceless, those who are marginalized, those who seek direction.
They should be able to turn to the faith community to find that direction.
We are to minimize anger, polarization.
Anything that seeks to diminish our relationship with one another as human beings, we should be trying to somehow mitigate that.
We also have to be willing to speak truth to power, no matter what the situation, no matter what the scenario.
What I can say about the Council of Baptist Pastors of Detroit and Vicinity is that we have very, very good leadership.

I'm very proud of Dr. Oscar King, our president, who has been very deliberate, who has sought to get information, who has continually and consistently sought to gather information so that he can make an informed decision about what he should say and when he should say it to the Mayor.
He has not been driven by the spotlight.
He has not been driven by pressures, both political and public.
He has been very deliberate about making an informed decision, and I commend him for that.
All right.
Thank you so much for your time.
Thank you for having me.
Bertram Marks is an attorney for the Council of Baptist Pastors for Detroit and Vicinity.
He joined us from the studios of the NPR member station WDET in Detroit.
House Democrats have left Washington for suburban Virginia, where they're holding their annual retreat right now.

Hey, Sue.
Hey, Ailsa.

If you're talking about legislation that has become law, the most significant achievement is probably the spending bill that ended the longest government shutdown in history.
Yeah.
But that has also led to a fight over a national emergency declaration that has put Democrats on - well, on a long-term fight with the president.
So I'm not sure anyone's really out there calling that a clear win for the new majority.
But with divided government, I think Democrats see a lot of their purpose is about creating a contrast with the president and with the Republican Party.

And when - if you look at the legislation that they are - have already passed and are soon to pass, it does kind of tell you a story in that one of the throughlines in this agenda is the Democratic Party is really advocating for a much bigger role for the federal government in day-to-day life here.
They've done things from past bills to make Election Day a federal holiday, to create automatic voter registration, to mandate federal mandates for equal pay for women.
Legislation coming down the pike soon are bills for a federal minimum wage, to increase it to up to $15 an hour.

I also think if you look at the big-idea, philosophical debates the Democratic Party is having right now - Medicare for All, the Green New Deal - it's the kind of thing that reminds people that the Democratic Party is, you know - it's a party of bigger government.
That's not a new idea, but in 2019, I think they're a lot less unapologetic about that fact.
Yeah.

That is a preview of every Republican attack ad you're probably going to hear in the 2020 battleground races for...
Right.

I did talk to Rhode Island Democratic Congressman David Cicilline.
He's a member of leadership, and I asked him about the socialism attack line that Republicans are lodging about their agenda.
And this is what he said.
You know, they made those same arguments when Social Security and Medicare were created.
It's socialism.

I talked to many of them today that say they just don't think they're going to be vulnerable to it.

I mean, there is such an ideological divide between Democrats and President Trump.
